< Karsten Wade
I'm going to take a shot at starting a thread in here (haven't used RocketChat before) -- Defining DCI
1st, I think it makes sense that we have a consensus on what terms used to describe the WG mean, at least to us in this context.
Damn, this isn't really about defining ... maybe I need to retitle :)
I do think people will ask this of us.

And to honest I don't think 'diversity' and 'inclusion' are difficult to define -- they are objective, binary conditions. If we are looking at e.g. gender diversity, there either is or is not a diverse representation.
Maybe 'inclusion' is potentially subjective, but when paired with 'diversity', it's clear the meaning is something inclusive or exclusive of the diversities focused on. Something like that?
I don't have 'civility' so clear in my mind, in that I think it's most often a very subjectively-tuned point of disagreement. Your joke is my poke is their yoke.

I wonder about 'regional' diversity since we're an international group and many do not participate in person? The rest seems clear.
I will attend Wednesday's meeting due to a schedule conflict. I am available to draft or edit group materials. Thanks, Kelly

@KellyCooper : I originally had cultural diversity, but I am not sure that is what we want either. I am looking to see if we are too heavily focused on a single region (e.g., the US or North America) to see if that is hurting our overall diversity (not just gender diversity)
@tkuhrt Could be there's a couple of words added to clarify. The idea works, a bit more clarity on why/what may improve data. Maybe regional (geographic representation) diversity....
@Dan et.al : I will be unable to make our working group call tomorrow
Has joined the channel.

Some of the meeting schedules are difficult for people from different time zones like East Asia..The DCI WG meeting as per Japanese Standard time starts at 2:30am which I think is difficult to attend..same is the challenge for ANZ and APAC countries..It shall be great if we can review potential solution for that to begin with Time Zone Diversity..

Will it be possible to quantify the participation from different geographies and promote where there are large opportunities of inclusion..I think this might also boost a diversity in perspective on Hyperledger and eventually a higher level of awareness..

@Starseven -- thanks for bringing up the issue of geographic diversity.  i agree this is important and there is much to do here.  for instance, i'd like to see us map the distribution of time zones attending all of the community calls in a given week and see how evenly distributed participation was.  i suspect that there will be areas where few people are calling in from.  we could then make recommendations about how to be more inclusion in those time zones, such as rotating meeting times, and then measure if those recommendations are helping or not.
And also making more use of asynchronous collaboration over email, wiki, and chat; minimizing meetings wherever possible.

Hi everyone, I've synthesized all the feedback into a final draft of the survey. 
As suggested by I think @Silona I've put it in a google doc so that it can be copied into survey monkey using Hyperledger/LF's account.
In synthesizing all the drafts, I did not add any new questions which would have prompted another TSC review. Instead I focused on being concise and consistent wherever possible.
After staff gets the opportunity to add these questions into survey monkey we can review the layout there.
Here's the link to the google doc: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1OSoQIDQK7utlmIGKBmKGJasZ_J7jPOwPIIDBbSFwTno/edit?usp=sharing

My intent is that we not make more revision there but instead review what it looks like in survey monkey. From experience the choice selection and other aspects are best reviewed on the survey platform itself.
You can also send out a link to a preview from Survey Monkey. That is what I did so that people could play with the survey and see how it works.
Are folks around to meet live this week? (Roughly 32 hrs from now)
I am available
Let's plan on dialing in (in about 1.5 hrs from now). Might be just a few of us but still worthwhile.

The Linux Foundation’s CommunityBridge engineers are working on a tool to measure the health of critical open source projects and one of the key areas identified is QA Testing.  They request that our communities provide  honest and detailed information on testing tools and methodologies you use in your projects for us to come up with a detailed analysis, which they will share with all respondents and projects. https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/9H5G2GV. Welcome Peter!

Hi All, since we didn't have time to get to the proposed motions for the TSC during our last call I would like to attempt to agree on these as a group offline. Reason being, the upcoming TSC meeting is the last one of the year and it would be great to head into 2021 with our focus on setting these in motion. For easy reference you can find the motions for review just under the GB section https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/DCI/Turning+Recommendations+into+Proposed+Motions+for+the+GB+and+TSC
Feel free to comment here or directly on the Wiki as you prefer

@lnuon -- i agree that it is a good thing for the group to collaborate more in offline ways vs needing to do everything in a call.  and thanks for posting here -- it would also be good to get more discussions going on chat.  the last post in this channel is back in june.  since this channel hasn't been very active though people may not be paying attention.  i'd suggest posting on the list too about trying to finalize the TSC motions to see if we get responses there too.
Will do! Great suggestion. Thx.

@davidwboswell Off-topic, maybe interesting fact: 
I was about to post here this morning when I decided that to optimize for message reach and  compared the number of members here to the members on the dci-wg mailing list. I ended up going with the mailing list because it has significantly more members than the channel here (and I didn't have a specific preference over IM or email)

@peter_somogyvari -- i feel like this is one thing we could do better in the community.  you made the right call about where to post, but for someone new to the community they could easily post to channels that aren't active and then never hear back from anyone.  a community with lots of inactive channels and contribution paths isn't super inclusive so we could do more to prune things, IMO.

Just an idea, maybe there could be a synchronization feature where bots cross-post on both communication platforms (email, RocketChat) so that at any point in time both have the union of all messages posted on either one of them.
It would also have the benefit of not having to double post when you really want to make sure that everyone gets the message (I always double post our weekly meeting agenda document link).
Downside (I guess) is that people subscribed to both with notifications enabled would get everything twice, but that would be an easy adjustment for them to mute either the emails or RocketChat depending on what their preferred interface is.
I have zero experience with setting up anything like this for RocketChat but have seen these kind of messaging integrations a lot on other places like Slack, Telegram, Discord, etc.

It would also have the benefit of not having to double post when you really want to make sure that everyone gets the message (I always double post our weekly meeting agenda document link).

I have zero experience with setting up anything like this for RocketChat but have seen these kind of messaging integrations a lot on other places like Slack, Telegram, Discord, etc. @davidwboswell

I'd def. find it useful. Since we're on the topic another pesky tool related thing I've had on my list to look into is the cal. functionality. @KOttoni covered a few different ways I could pull meetings into my cal. but I don't recall if any of them kept your personal cal. up to date when changes were made to event.
yes, the calendar issue isn't as straight forward as it could be

and cross posting across chat and list could work, although as peter points out that could just double communication for people on both.  my 2 cents would be having a way to indicate when channels are inactive -- not get rid of them but make it clear to people that they may not get a response if they use it.

I added a section to the Developer Guide Outline Draft regarding the fair processing of pull requests. It ended up being a little longer/wordier than I thought it would be so I'm definitely open to ideas on how it could be compressed a bit. :-)

I added a section to the Developer Guide Outline Draft regarding the fair processing of pull requests. It ended up being a little longer/wordier than I thought it would be so I'm definitely open to ideas on how it could be compressed a bit. :-)
https://wiki.hyperledger.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=50136252
Thanks for kicking this off @peter_somogyvari. At first glance it looks solid, having more to work with is much better than not enough. @grace.hartley and I will review and provide feedback.

Thanks for kicking off the doc, @peter_somogyvari. I don't think it's too lengthy. I appreciated the examples. I'm not sure if we want to add to this doc or not but I also added in a brief section around facilitating chat channels in an inclusive manner too.

Also, FYI to the group, I'm OOO tomorrow so I won't be on the working group call. Just confirming @peter_somogyvari that we still haven't received approval from INI on the dci-lint tool? We're still pending submitting the proposal to the TSC since that it hasn't been approved yet.
@grace.hartley My pleasure and thanks for adding that section, I think it's needed for sure!

@grace.hartley Confirmed, still no approval unfortunately. 

It has progressed a lot from how it was since we last spoke, but the progress also unearthed that it likely won't get merged as is and may even need a complete re-work for the configuration file to have a different format. 
In addition to that the INI will potentially want to do some research into other similar tools as DCI Lint themselves to get better informed on their approach to this. There's a version of events where all this will happen quite fast and then the PR will get merged soon, but I would estimate that it will be a little while longer.

Depending on the level of urgency to get the TSC recommendations out of the door, we could take a second stab at looking into some temporary measure to bridge the gap between the present and a future potential INI approval for the PR.
(I still prefer to avoid maintaining the word list in the DCI Lint repo, especially after seeing how much work goes into the INI - but there are other avenues we could put a little more effort into exploring as a temporary measure)
No worries @grace.hartley , recording and meeting notes will be posted. And I'll add discussing potential solutions in lieu of the PR approval to the agenda.
Does anyone else have agenda items they would like to discuss?
